comments.commentBody: @John David:  See my earlier recommendations to you.

There are different rules for the two parties, that is all I know. Here is a link which may help explain the extremely confusing primary process:

http://frontloading.blogspot.com/p/2016-presidential-primary-calendar.html
Super Tuesday has the same effect on the other side of the aisle.

Unintended consequences? I think not.

The Rs have been dog-whistling the themes that Trump is now, well, trumpeting, for 35 years, since Reagan's "states rights" speech.

The Rs have consistently championed the degradation of the education system, and consistently belittled any sign of erudition or intelligence.

The Rs have consistently and vocally predicated government as the problem that has to be, or should be, eradicated, and ridiculed any consideration of experience or competence.

The intended consequence has always been to appeal to racist, xenophobic ignoramuses, and to create more of the same.

Not unintended. Very intended indeed. They just don't like being on the receiving end of the biliousness they have unleashed.
Let me introduce myself -- I am extremely enthusiastic about Sec Clinton, and hope she becomes the Prez.  She will make a great one.
and party candidates are "chosen" by selection committees made of the party establishment, not the voters.  No thanks...
John Oliver's piece on "Donald Drumpf"  was the best attack on The Donald I have seen by anyone...leagues better than the crude junior high stuff from Cruz and Rubio. Check it out on YouTube.

@ Jonathan: In the hypothetical match-up between Trump and Bernie, who do you think wins? The person who is actively disliked/hated by 75% of the population (for whatever reason: maybe they have been insulted by him, maybe they are "of the establishment", etc.) or the "Socialist"?

If you said Trump, I'm sorry to say that I probably agree with you. It is a nice thought experiment for how much you think America hates the idea of Socialism, though.

"Yet Trump’s support has stayed firm even as he has made statements that I would have thought would offend yuge numbers of people, including women, Hispanics, Muslims and the disabled."

I think this should tell you all you need to know about who is supporting Trump and why waiting for the other shoe to drop isn't going to work. Trump has been throwing so many shoes on the floor since he started his campaign that everyone who could be alienated already has been. So, unless you can demonstrate that the electorate who will vote in the Republican primaries in the remaining states is somehow mostly comprised of the people Trump has offended, I don't see how he can't be the nominee.

(Nice reference to Bayesians, by the way, Justin. I have just revised upward my prior probability of the goodness of your future articles.)
Well said, exactly!!!
And Al Franken... more than once... The only shred of dignity I have is at least I'm not from California...
Unless Kasich drops out I don't think Rubio will win a single state.

I guess the political campaign is putting us all on edge -- I'm surprised at the hostility to Mr. Cohn in the comments. All he's doing is offering some plausible numerical scenarios for tomorrow's election, and focusing on the figure who, by all accounts, does appear to the main challenger to Mr. Trump (whatever his merits as a candidate or human being might be). Give Mr. Cohn a break, if you don't want to read about numbers, read something else!
So... Minnesota.  That's a lot of ink to arrive at the conclusion (ours, not yours, it seems) that Rubio is basically finished in about 15 days, if not before.  Will you do Mr. Cruz next?

Definitely. I can't figure out why the New York Times, Nate Cohn, and the press like Rubio so much. Why? The guy has extreme views and is completely controlled by the 1% donors, whose bidding he would do no matter what they ask, such as the 2013 immigration reform and cutting taxes for the 1%.  He is not his own man at all. Maybe the NYT should write an article about his being in the pocket of Norman Braman and NY city donors, instead of Nate Cohn wishfully imagining him somehow winning the nomination by delegate counting tricks.
I completed the entire puzzle but could not solve the theme.  WAY to obscure for my taste.  Thumbs down.

Mr Benton, what do you qualify list of accomplishments. If you anything about politics it is about mudslinging which Trump was doing it from the start. Rubio got in a bit late but that is the name of the game. There is also plenty of information and videos outlining his view of the future of this country but frankly the media is more enthralled with the circus that Trump is. If you believe the media is going to reward a candidate for sticking to his message with solutions think again, there is no room for that type of coverage when ratings are at hand. He has been a Senator since 2010, far more experience than the President that was in for less than 4 and before that, well nada. It is obvious you do not ingest the information that is relevant to this election, that is solutions.
Good question. Answer: They're in the pay or the same corporate interests that determine what gets printed to keep the existing wounds in US society bleeding.

Why does the media (this article) insist on calling Rubio a moderate?  He is a baby of the Tea Party and holds vile and extreme views on abortion, medical care, international diplomacy, etc. Before the Cruz-Trump realities of 2016 he would have been identified as what he is: a far right ideologue of weak character, and very dangerous.
Hey victor, Lincoln failed at many things and then became our greatest president.

As a retired small business entrepreneur I can tell that you have no experience creating businesses. I created seven; several failed; several were mediocre, and several were home runs. That's the way it works and makes possible non-creative people like you drawing a paycheck each week from people like Trump. It is extremely rare for an entrepreneur to go a career without some failures. In the end you add up your wins and losses and hope you come out well. Trump has come out exceptionally well and given tens of thousands their weekly paycheck. Unless you work for the government, you work for a company that was started by one or more entrepreneurs.

Failures at the highest levels in America are rewarded with ever-higher profile positions, salary and influence. Look at Hank Paulson, Tim Geitner and Carly Fiorina, not to mention George Bush. Look at all the ex-politicians who become lobbyists for the money, and all the lobbyists writing legislation on behalf of corporations that the lazy, ignorant members of Congress can't, or can't be bothered to, read. Donald Drumph becoming president would be completely fitting, in this scenario.

Voted for Obama twice and now considering Donald Trump. Why,? you ask? Cruz is too conservative, will fight with his own party AND the Democrats. Rubio nothing there to reccomend, he's is bought and sold by the party, his best skill is debating which really  do much for a president. Kasich would be my plan B; experienced, level-headed. Trump's ego will be the motivation for working on the problems of this country. It would drive him NOT to go down in history as a failure.

I agree but am still stopped in my tracks that people are supporting him. I have yet to read a rationale I can believe. If we grant every word of what you said, how is this happening? People are angry? Yes, but totally irrational, supporting a man who has contempt for everything and everyone, no doubt including his own supporters? What words would explain this?
The publican party has been playing race politics for decades.  It is breathtaking to seem them call out Trump for what they turned into an art form.
The most so prescient assessment I have read yet evidently many have come to that conclusion.

The real reason Republicans find themselves in the situation they are in is not the primary machinations, but Nixon's Southern strategyism, Ronald Reagan's blame the government scapegoating, George H. W. Atwater's bigoted fear mongering, Clinton hating impeachment conspiracyism, George W. Bush's laissez-faire neo-conism and the bigoted obstructionism that refuses to acknowledge Barak Obama as the legitimate President of We the People of the United States of America.

Republicans have been breeding hate, bigotry and anger in primary voters for many years.

Hillary Clinton is a flawed candidate indeed -- too militaristic for me -- but compare her preaching for more "love and kindness" just yesterday.

I am unmoved by Wenar's argument. It is facile. Like Steven Pinker, he is an apologist for a thoroughly corrupt human civilization. The society we have built is morally despicable, demented in a million ways. Anyone with any sentience at all can feel how rapacious and brutal it is, in matters both big and small. It destroys any sense of well-being and health at almost every turn of ordinary living. It has become intolerable. Putting an optimistic spin on it all is an exercise in contorted perception, and fools no one. His argument implodes on his pet phrase,"at least this far," used repeatedly. Mr. Wenar, wake up! We've created a monstrous culture, and it is eating itself. From the historical record, it couldn't be clearer that we are a failed species. In the decades to come, we will get what we deserve. And the earth and its non-human survivors will be delivered from the scourge of the diseased animal, the ill-named homo sapiens.
Unfortunately true - they expected Obama to have the country and economy completely turned around by 2010.

This isn't a Trump thing.  It's a population thing.  It's a loss of self identity by a very large, very ignorant and very lazy population which increasingly takes its direction from reality tv and avoids looking in the mirror for any reason other than to check  clothing and makeup.  And no matter how often they get burned, they scream for a savior every four years and turn against them thirty days after the inaugural ball.  It's quite horrifying, but for the first time in six decades, I no longer feel Americans have the will, the intellect or the spiritual core to save this country from a disaster on its way. But, as long as we have America's Got Talent...what the heck! Cue the theme from Titanic.

When I was in elementary school, I was in an underfunded district in what was then one of the poorer states of the US. The curriculum was by and large stifling, the atmosphere misogynistic. An awkward, unathletic kid, I was bullied routinely.  If anyone had tried to test me on joy, I would have failed miserably -- or I would have received a placeholder grade in lieu of failure, as I did in one subset of the conduct marks.  At the very least, I would have found it patronizing. My prospects in life changed overnight when we moved to a different district, a more affluent and less rigid one in the same state. It is all well and good to preach about grit and to encourage perseverance, but don't forget that the most important factors are genuine opportunity for all learners, social and economic equity, support for diverse types of families,  and a commitment to ending discrimination.
